abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Human Immunodeficiency
            Virus (HIV)/Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
            Response Project for Sierra Leone were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            design of an HIV/AIDS intervention in a post-conflict
            setting should be greatly simplified to accommodate capacity
            and institutional constraints that often exist in such
            settings. For instance, constraints in terms of geographic
            coverage or transportation links in a post-conflict setting
            are common and can significantly impede implementation and
            scope of activities. Consideration should be given to
            phasing of community response and engagement in settings
            with limited in-country capacity. Insufficient data at
            project design can significantly hamper targeting of
            high-risk groups and the need to improve sentinel
            surveillance among most at risk populations cannot be
            overstated. Bank responsiveness (or lack thereof) to
            implementation challenges has direct consequences on
            development outcomes. The responsiveness of Bank management
            and Government to project management challenges can have
            deleterious effects on project outcomes if not dealt with
            appropriately and in a timely fashion. High level political
            commitment provides a good platform for ensuring public
            attention. The active and vocal support from the President,
            parliamentarians, and other political officers helped to
            raise the visibility and attention given to HIV/AIDS issues
            in the public domain. Contracting a financial and
            procurement management agent helps to mitigate the financial
            risk exposure of HIV/AIDS projects not only at the national
            but also decentralized and community levels, where
            governance and accountability mechanisms are not well
            developed and understood.

9739979.trustfund:

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - HIV/AIDS Response Project
            and Health Sector Reconstruction and Development Project
            (HSRDP) : environmental assessments

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for both
            the HIV/AIDS Response Project (SHARP) and the Health Sector
            Reconstruction and Development Project (HSRDP) describes the
            comprehensive waste management plan made to counter
            anticipated negative environmental impacts. Appropriate
            design, sites and operation of sanitary landfills, leachate
            treatment and control, and water quality testing will reduce
            the risk of drinking water contamination. High temperature
            incineration, installation of flue gas cleaning devices, air
            quality testing, and non-incineration of materials
            containing chlorine or heavy metals will prevent release of
            pollutants into the air. Provision and ensuring the routine
            use of protective clothing, staff training, and teaching
            first aid will reduce the occurrence of occupational
            hazards. Limiting access to disposal sites, fencing of
            disposal sites, separating cells for medical wastes, and
            sensitizing the public through the media, particularly
            radio, television, posters, leaflets, newspapers, etc., will
            minimize disease transmission. Furthermore, all health care
            facilities will be equipped with appropriate equipment,
            materials, and facilities for collecting, managing, and
            transporting medical waste. Incinerators will be built and
            adapted for use in health facilities. Infectious hospital
            waste will be disposed of in sanitary landfills with set precautions.

5085449.trustfund:
TF026795-PHRD-SIERRA LEONE HIV/AIDS
            MULTI-SECTOR RESPONSE PROJECT,TF058290-SIERRA LEONE - CONDITIONAL CASH
            TRANSFER PILOT

abstracts.cdata!:
The HIV/AIDS Response Project for Sierra
            Leone will assist the government to organize a response to
            the growing disease, within the context of the Multi-Country
            HIV/AIDS Program for the Africa Region (MAP II). In
            accordance with the main goal of the MAP, the development
            objectives of this four-year project are to contribute to
            reducing HIV/AIDS prevalence and mitigate the impact of
            HIV/AIDS on persons infected or affected by HIV/AIDS. There
            are four project components. They finance capacity building,
            and policy and program coordination; multi-sector responses
            to HIV/AIDS prevention and care; health sector responses to
            HIV/AIDS, STI/TB, and other opportunistic infection
            management, including prevention and care; and community and
            civil society initiatives (including communities,
            nongovernmental organizations, religious groups, and the
            private sector).
